qas.question: What sorts of departments might one see in a major department store?

answers.text: clothing, furniture, home appliances, toys, cosmetics, gardening, toiletries, sporting goods

qas.question: Who started influencing department stores in the 1970's?
What has begun pressuring department stores in more recent years?
Other than at the check-out lanes at the front of a store, where may customers check out?

answers.text: at sales counters within each department.

plausible_answers.text: clothing, furniture, home appliances, toys, cosmetics, gardening, toiletries, sporting goods

qas.question: What sorts of departments might one see in a minor department store?
Who started influencing department stores in the 1990's?
Who stopped influencing department stores in the 1970's?
What has stopped pressuring department stores in more recent years?

plausible_answers.text: at sales counters within each department

qas.question: Other than at the check-out lanes at the front of a store, where can't customers check out?

context: Department stores today have sections that sell the following: <a0_0><b4_0>clothing, furniture, home appliances, toys, cosmetics, gardening, toiletries, sporting goods<b4_0/><a0_0/>, do it yourself, paint, and hardware and additionally select other lines of products such as food, books, jewelry, electronics, stationery, photographic equipment, baby products, and products for pets. Customers check out near the front of the store or, alternatively, <a3_0><b8_0>at sales counters within each department<b8_0/>.<a3_0/> Some are part of a retail chain of many stores, while others may be independent retailers. In the 1970s, they came under heavy pressure from <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>discounters<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>. Since 2010, they have come under even heavier pressure from <a2_0><b7_0>online stores such as Amazon<b7_0/>.
